High-silica Hβ zeolites for catalytic hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes in water Sharmin Sultana Poly a S.M.A. Hakim Siddiki a ⁎ Abeda S. Touchy a Shunsaku Yasumura a Takashi Toyao a b Zen Maeno a Ken-ichi Shimizu a b ⁎ a Institute for Catalysis, Hokkaido University, N-21, W-10, Sapporo 001-0021, Japan Institute for Catalysis Hokkaido University N-21, W-10 Sapporo 001-0021 Japan b Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries, Kyoto University, Katsura, Kyoto 615-8520, Japan Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries Kyoto University Katsura Kyoto 615-8520 Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Institute for Catalysis, Hokkaido University, N-21, W-10, Sapporo 001-0021, Japan. Institute for Catalysis Hokkaido University N-21, W-10 Sapporo 001-0021 Japan Graphical abstract We investigated the hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes in water using 24 types of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts and found that Hbeta (Hβ) zeolite with a relatively high Si/Al ratio (Si/Al = 75), Hβ-75, is an effective catalyst. Hβ-75 showed wide substrate scope, good reusability, and applicability in gram-scale synthesis for both types of reactions. The effects of hydrophobicity, acidity, and the size of zeolite pores were also comprehensively studied through the hydration of hydrophilic and hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes with different molecular sizes using two types of zeolite (Hβ and HZSM5). The high yields obtained using the Hβ-75 catalyst in the hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes are attributed to the hydrophobic interaction between zeolite pores with the substrates, as well as the relatively large pore size. Keywords Hydration Epoxides Alkynes Zeolites Hydrophobic interaction Aqueous media 1 Introduction Hydration and hydrolysis of organic compounds are fundamental reactions in organic synthesis. In the chemical industry, the hydration of epoxides, alkenes, alkynes, nitriles and hydrolysis of esters are particularly important in the production of oxygen-containing organic chemicals [1,2]. Ring-opening hydration of epoxides [1–19] forms 1,2-diols as intermediates for the manufacture of polyester resins and other functional chemicals. Hydration of alkynes [1,2,21–39] forms carbonyl compounds as key intermediates for the bulk- and fine-chemical industries. Conventionally, mineral acids, such as sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid, have been used as catalysts in many industrial hydration/hydrolysis processes, but the current processes have significant problems, such as corrosion of the reactor, toxicity, difficulty in the reuse of catalysts, and the costs associated with neutralization of the waste acid [1,2]. Extensive studies have been reported on the development of new catalytic hydration/hydrolysis methods, which are more environmentally benign than the current methods. Various heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., resins [3,4], Mo-V oxides [5], Nb-based oxides [6–8], immobilized transition metal complexes [10–16]) and homogeneous catalysts (e.g., metal salts [1], cyclic amines, Co-complexes [17]) have been evaluated for use in the ring-opening hydration of epoxides. For the hydration of alkynes, a substantial amount of effort has been devoted to the exploration of replacing toxic Hg(II)-base catalysts with alternatives, including homogeneous transition metal catalysts (Fe [18,19], Ir [20], Ag [21], Co [22–24], and Au [25]), mineral acids in an ionic liquid [26] or aqueous microemulsions [27], and heterogeneous catalysts, such as polymer-supported sulfonic acid [28], Sn-W mixed oxide [32], and immobilized transition metals [33–37]. However, homogeneous catalytic systems often suffer from difficulties associated with the separation of the catalysts. In the context of transition metal-containing heterogeneous catalysts, there are some risk of producing contaminated hydration products. These are detrimental from an environmental perspective. Although organic heterogeneous catalysts, such as resins and polymer-supported sulfonic acids, have the potential to overcome these issues, there are still problems concerning low reusability due to their instability. Accordingly, the demand for inorganic and transition-metal-free heterogeneous catalysts for hydration of epoxides and alkynes has begun to increase significantly in recent years. Brønsted acidic zeolite has shown promising in the development of environmentally benign and practical catalysts used to produce contamination-free products due to general stability, easy handling, low cost, and the absence of transition-metal species. It is known that the hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of aluminosilicate zeolites depend on the Si/Al ratio, and zeolites with high Si/Al ratio, known as high-silica zeolite, have high hydrophobicity owing to the nonpolar nature of the SiOSi surface [38–46]. The pore sizes of zeolites are closer to organic molecules and the larger pore facilitates the rapid diffusion of bulky organic molecules. To date, a few studies have been conducted on the hydration of epoxides and alkynes using aluminosilicate zeolites. Chihara et al. reported the effect of organic solvents on the catalysis in hydration of 1,2-epoxyhexane [9], but other catalytic properties, such as substrate scope and catalyst reusability, were not investigated. As for the hydration of alkynes, Moreau et al. discussed the role of hydrophobic effect using dealuminated zeolites in the hydration of phenylacetylene in polar protic solvent (EtOH) [29]. The zeolite-catalyzed hydration of alkynes conducted without an organic solvent was examined by Nama et al. and Tang et al. [30,31] However, comprehensive studies on the effects of acidity and pore size of zeolites on catalysis have yet to be adequately conducted. Recently, our research group found that the proton-exchanged *BEA zeolite (Hβ) with a high Si/Al ratio and large pore size catalyzed efficient hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters in water and studied the roles of hydrophobicity, acidity, and pore size [47]. In this work, we report that hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes can be smoothly catalyzed in water by high-silica Hβ zeolite. Detailed catalytic studies revealed good reusability and a wide substrate scope of our method. Furthermore, to elucidate the role of hydrophobicity, acidity, and pore size of zeolites, the hydration of hydrophilic/hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes with different molecular sizes were conducted using two types of zeolites (Hβ and HZSM5) with different Si/Al ratios. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Commercial compounds (Tokyo Chemical Industry or Sigma-Aldrich) were used without further purification. GC (Shimadzu GC-2014) and GCMS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) analyses were carried out with Ultra ALLOY+-1 capillary column (Frontier Laboratories Ltd.) with N2 and He as the carrier. Column chromatography was performed with silica gel 60 (spherical, 40–100 μm, Kanto Chemical Co. Ltd.). Molecular sieves 4 Å (MS4Å) was dehydrated at 100 °C. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The zeolites catalysts are designated as Hβ-x; x denotes the Si/Al ratio of the Hβ zeolite. Hβ-75 (JRC-Z-HΒ150, originally supplied from Clariant), Hβ-12.5 (JRC-Z-HΒ25), HMOR-45 (JRC-Z-HM90, originally supplied from Clariant), TiO2 (JRC-TIO-4), CeO2 (JRC-CEO-3), amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-2, Al2O3 content = 13.75 wt%, surface area = 560 m2 g−1) were supplied from Catalysis Society of Japan. Hβ-20 (HSZ-940HOA), Hβ-255 (HSZ-980HOA), HZSM5-20 (HSZ-840HOA) and HY-50 (HSZ-385HUA) were commercially purchased from Tosoh Co. Hβ-5 (HSZ-940HOA), which was synthesized according to the previous paper [54], was supplied from UniZeo Co., Ltd. HZSM5-11 was prepared by calcination (550 °C, 3 h) of NH4-ZSM5 (Si/Al = 11, HSZ-820NHA). HZSM5-75 and HZSM5-150 were supplied from N.E. CHEMCAT Co. Niobic acid was kindly supplied by CBMM, and Nb2O5 was prepared by calcination of the niobic acid at 500 °C for 3 h. SiO2 (Q-10) was supplied from Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd. ZrO2 and SnO2 were prepared by calcination (500 °C, 3 h) of ZrO2·nH2O and H2SnO3 (Kojundo Chemical Laboratory Co., Ltd.). Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was prepared by titrating H3PW12O40 (Nippon Inorganic Color and Chemicals Co.) by aqueous solution of Cs2CO3 (0.10 mol dm−3) with vigorous stirring, followed by centrifuging and drying at 200 °C. Montmorillonite K10 clay and sulfonic resins (Amberlyst-15 and Nafion-SiO2 composite) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Scandium(III) trifluoromethanesulfonate, Sc(OTf)3, and p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry. 2.3 IR measurements The NH3-adsorption IR (infrared) study was carried with JASCO FT/IR-4200 spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector using a flow-type IR cell connected to a flow reaction system. The IR disc of the sample (40 mg, 20 mm ϕ) was first dehydrated under He flow at 500 °C, and then a background spectrum was taken under He flow at 200 °C. Then, NH3 (1%) was introduced to the sample, followed by purging by He, and by IR measurement of adsorbed NH3 at 200 °C. 2.4 Catalytic tests The heterogeneous catalysts, stored under ambient conditions, were used without any pretreatment. Typically, each of the terminal alkyne, internal alkyne and epoxide in 1 mmol was subjected for hydration with 1 mL of H2O in presence of 10 mg, 30 mg and 5 mg of catalysts respectively. The reaction mixture was added to a reaction tube (Pyrex pressure tube, 13 mL), with a magnetic stirrer bar and placed in a heated reactor at reflux condition under air with stirring at 400 rpm. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was diluted by acetone (7 mL) and n-dodecane (0.2 mmol) was added as an internal standard and the mixture was analyzed by GC-FID and GC-MS. The catalyst was separated through filtration and solvent was evaporated from the reaction mixture. The product was isolated by column chromatography using silica gel 60 (spherical, 40–100 μm, Kanto Chemical Co. Ltd.) with hexane/ethyl acetate (60/40 to 80/20) as the eluting solvent. The GC-FID sensitivities of the products were determined using commercial diols and ketones or the isolated products after the reaction. The final product was analyzed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and GC-MS equipped with the same column as GC-FID. 2.5 Adsorption experiments Adsorption of n-dodecane in liquid phase was carried out as follows. n-Dodecane (1 mmol) in/on 1 mL water was stirred with zeolite powder (50 mg) for 15 h at room temperature, followed by centrifugation to separate the solids from the liquid. Then, acetone (6 mL) and the internal standard (n-decane 0.2 mmol) were added to the liquid, and the mixture was analyzed by GC-FID. H2O-TPD measurement was conducted with BELCAT (MicrotracBEL Inc.). The sample (100 mg of Hβ, Si/Al = 5, 12.5, 20, 75, 255) was mounted on a quartz tube and was treated with vaporized H2O (1–2 μl) in a flow of He (30 cm3 min−1) at 100 °C. After that, the catalyst was heated linearly at 10 °C min−1 until 600 °C in a flow of He (30 cm3 min−1), and outlet gases (H2O, m/e = 18) were analyzed by the mass spectrometer (BEL Mass, (MicrotracBEL Inc.)). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance for hydration of epoxides Ring-opening hydration of a model epoxide, 1,2-epoxycyclohexane (1a), was performed in water. Table 1 summarizes the yield of 1,2-cyclohexanediol (2a) for the hydration of 1a (1 mmol) with H2O (1 mL) at 50 °C for 12 h in the presence of 5 mg of the catalysts. Prior to stirring and heating the mixture, the epoxide (oil droplet) was on the water surface, while the solid catalysts were in water. The reaction did not occur in the absence of the catalyst as shown in entry 1. A total of 21 types of heterogeneous catalysts (entries 2–22) and 3 types of homogeneous catalysts (entries 23–25) were screened. Proton-exchanged zeolites (entries 2–10) showed moderate to high yields (43–98%) of 2a, while Hβ catalysts (entries 5–8) showed higher yields than other zeolites, such as HZSM5 (entries 2–4), HY (entry 9), and HMOR (entry 10). The yields associated with the Hβ catalysts depended on the Si/Al ratio, and among the Hβ zeolite with intermediate Si/Al values, Hβ-75 (entry 7) gave the highest yield of 98%. Among various metal oxides (entries 11–17), ZrO2 (entry 13), and Nb2O5 (entry 17) showed relatively high yields (70–77%). Niobic acid (entry 18) [48], a heteropoly acid salt Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 (entry 19) is a well-known water-tolerant solid acid [2]. These catalysts showed lower yields (59–75%) than Hβ-75 (entry 7). Commercially available solid acids, montmorillonite K10 clay (entry 20), Nafion/SiO2 composite (entry 21), and Amberlyst-15 (entry 22, acidic resins with sulfonic acid groups) also showed lower yields (32–74%) than Hβ-75. Homogeneous Brønsted acids, H2SO4 (entry 23), p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA, entry 24), and a water-tolerant homogeneous Lewis acid, Sc(OTf)3 (entry 25) [49], showed lower yields (34–78%) than Hβ-75. In all cases, the selectivity to 2a was over 99%. It is noteworthy that Hβ-75 shows a higher yield than conventional homogeneous catalysts under the same catalyst weight conditions. We also compared the initial reaction rates over Hβ-75, ZrO2, and Nb2O5 (See the Supporting Information). TOF values, normalized by the number of acid sites, are also given. The TOF value observed for Hβ-75 (106 h−1) was comparable to those for ZrO2 and Nb2O5 (136 h−1 and 144 h−1, respectively). From the screening results, Hβ-75 is the most effective catalyst for the ring-opening hydration of the epoxide 1a in water. Having identified the optimal catalyst (Hβ-75), Hβ-75 was then used to investigate the catalytic performance of our method. The ring-opening hydration of a variety of epoxides was conducted. Table 2 lists the yields of the corresponding glycols. Hβ-75 smoothly catalyzed the hydration of and derivatives of cyclohexane oxide (entries 1–3), 1,2-epoxydodecane (entry 4), 1,2-epoxybutane (entry 5), styrene oxide (entry 6) and its derivative (entry 7), benzyl glycidyl ether (entry 8), and halogenated epoxides (entries 9–11) including epichlorohydrin (entry 11) were hydrated to corresponding glycols with relatively high yields, ranging from 73 to 98%. The epoxide groups were selectively transformed without changing other functional groups, such as vinyl, ether, ester, and the halogen groups. After the first cycle for the hydration of 1a to 2a (Table 2, entry 1), the Hβ-75 catalyst was separated from the mixture by centrifugation, followed by washing with acetone, drying at 90 °C for 3 h, and then reused. The yield for the fifth cycle (94%) was reasonably close to the yield in the first cycle (Fig. 1 gray), indicating that the Hβ-75 catalyst is recyclable. A gram-scale reaction of 1a (10 mmol) with a small amount of the catalyst for 72 h provided a 92% yield of 2a (Eq. (1)). Adopting the number of Brønsted acid sites in Hβ-75 (0.28 mmol g−1), the yield corresponds to the turnover number (TON) of 3300 (per number of acid sites), which is more than 3 times higher than that of the recently reported catalysts, including Sn-zeolite (977) [10], mesoporous silica-supported Fe (314) [11], and Co(salen)-OTs encapsulated in silica nanocages (345) [14]. (1) 3.2 Catalyst performance for hydration of alkynes Adopting a relatively bulky alkyne, diphenylacetylene (3a), as a model substrate, catalyst screening was conducted for the hydration of alkynes in water. Table 3 compares the yields of benzyl phenyl ketone (4a) in the hydration of 3a (1 mmol) with H2O (1 mL) under refluxing conditions for 18 h in the presence of 30 mg of the catalysts. Note that the yields of 4a were relatively close to the conversion of 3a for all the catalytic tests in Table 3. Substantially similar to the hydration of epoxide 1a, Hβ-75 (entry 7) showed the highest yield (98%) among the 21 types of heterogeneous catalysts (entries 2–22) and three types of homogeneous catalysts (entries 23–25). Table 4 shows yields of the corresponding ketones for the hydration of various alkynes in water. Phenylacetylene (entry 1), its derivatives with electron-donating (entries 2–4) and electron-withdrawing functional groups (entry 5), and internal alkynes (entries 6–8) were transformed to the corresponding ketones with exceptionally high yields (92–96%). Fig. 1 (black) shows the result of catalyst reuse. After the first cycle of the hydration of 3a to 4a (Table 3, entry 7), the catalyst was separated, washed, and then reused in the same manner as the previously discussed hydration of epoxides. The yield for the fifth cycle (89%) was similar to that for the first cycle, showing the recyclability of the Hβ-75 catalyst. Hβ-75 was applicable to gram-scale reactions of phenylacetylene and diphenylacetylene (10 mmol in each case), where the yields of the ketones were 97% and 92%, respectively (Eqs. (2) and (3)). (2) (3) 3.3 Hydrophobicity, hydrophilicity, and acidity of Hβ and HZSM5 vs. Si/Al ratio The results of catalyst screening show that the catalytic activity of Hβ for hydration of hydrophobic epoxide and alkyne depends on the Si/Al ratio. The Hβ with an intermediate Si/Al ratio (Hβ-75) showed the highest yields of product. To obtain the structural properties of zeolites for clarification of dominant factors that control the activity trends, quantitative analysis was used to evaluate the hydrophobicity, hydrophilicity, and acidity of zeolites, including Hβ with different Si/Al ratios. The results are summarized in Table 5 . It is well established that the amount of water adsorbed is a quantitative index for hydrophilicity of zeolites, which is strongly dependent on the Si/Al ratio. Several previous studies have reported that the amount of water adsorbed on H-MOR, H-ZSM5, and Hβ zeolites decreased with increasing the Si/Al ratio [41–43]. We have tested H2O-TPD for quantification of hydrophilicity of zeolites, and the results are presented in Fig. 2 . The profiles for the Hβ zeolites showed a desorption peak in the range of 100–400 °C, and the peak centers shifted toward higher temperature with decreases in the Si/Al ratio. The amount of H2O desorbed below 500 °C (nH2O) is used as a hydrophilicity index; the higher nH2O value implies higher hydrophilicity (Table 5). Results of this study indicated that the hydrophilicity of Hβ zeolites decreased with increasing the Si/Al ratio. Simply stated, the hydrophobicity of Hβ zeolites increased with the Si/Al ratio. This result is consistent with the recent reports by Otomo et al. [41] and Kobayashi et al. [42,43], in which the hydrophilicity of Hβ zeolites, estimated by vapor-phase water adsorption experiments, decreased with increases in the Si/Al ratio. Hydrophobicity of the zeolites was evaluated by adsorption experiment of n-dodecane on/in water at room temperature. Fig. 3 shows kinetic curves and the equilibrium amount of n-dodecane adsorbed. Note that the amount of n-dodecane (1 mmol) in water (170 g/L) is higher than the solubility of n-dodecane in water at 25 °C (3.7 mg/L), so the n-dodecane in the initial mixture does not dissolve in water but remains on the water surface (oil droplets). Zeolite powders are initially present in water. When the mixture is being stirred, n-dodecane can move into the zeolite via the water/oil/zeolite interface. We have used n-dodecane on/in water to evaluate the hydrophobicity of zeolites because the adsorption processes of n-dodecane should be similar to that of hydrophobic substrates during hydration reactions examined in this study. The amount of n-dodecane adsorbed to Hβ-75 increased over time, and the adsorption reached equilibrium within 15 h. The equilibrium adsorption value increased with an increase of Si/Al ratio, indicating that the hydrophobicity of Hβ zeolites increased with increases of Si/Al. Similar kinetic curves and equilibrium adsorption values were observed for a series of HZSM5 zeolites. The minimum cross-diameter (size) of n-dodecane (4.3 Å × 4.9 Å) was smaller than the pore sizes of Hβ and HZSM5 (7.6 Å × 7.3 Å and 5.6 Å × 5.3 Å, respectively), which is consistent with the observation of similar adsorption rates and trends. Acidity of Hβ was analyzed by the IR spectroscopy for ammonia (NH3) adsorbed on the zeolites. The spectra for Hβ with different Si/Al ratios and HZSM5-75 are presented in Fig. 4 . The integrated molar extinction coefficient (0.03 cm μmol−1) of the NH4 + in zeolites was determined. Using this coefficient in conjunction with the area intensities of the bands around 1454 cm−1 [50–53], the number of Brønsted acid sites in Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75 were calculated to be 0.28 mmol g−1 and 0.31 mmol g−1, respectively. The intensity of the band around 1454 cm−1 decreased with increases in the Si/Al ratio, which indicated that the number of the Brønsted acid site decreased with increases in the Si/Al ratio. The intensities of the band at 1640 cm−1 due to the coordinatively bound NH3 on Lewis acid [50–53] appeared to be relatively weak, revealing that the most of acid sites of Hβ and HZSM5-75 are Brønsted acid sites. The IR spectrum for NH3 adsorbed on NaZSM5-45 was recorded, with the peak observed around 1640 cm−1, indicating that NaZSM5-45 is Lewis acidic. 3.4 Effect of hydrophobicity of zeolites and substrates on the reaction rates To clarify the primary factors that control the activity trends in the zeolite-catalyzed hydration reactions, we first discuss the role of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites using HZSM5-75 and NaZSM5-45. HZSM5-75 displayed a much higher initial rate (36 mmol g−1 h−1) than NaZSM5-45 (6 mmol g−1 h−1) in the hydration of 1,2-epoxycyclohexane. A similar result was obtained in the hydration of phenylacetylene, where the initial rates of HZSM5-75 and NaZSM5-45 were 65 and 4 mmol g−1 h−1, respectively. Considering that HZSM5-75 is dominantly Brønsted acidic while NaZSM5-45 is Lewis acidic, Brønsted acid sites are the active sites for the hydration of epoxides and alkynes. Next, the hydrations of several hydrophilic and hydrophobic substrates were conducted using Hβ with different Si/Al ratios. The octanol/water partition coefficient (log Kow) and the solubility in water are shown as quantitative indexes for hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity indexes for each molecule, respectively, in Table 6 (as shown in the next section). Fig. 5 summarizes the reaction rates for various epoxides and alkynes for Hβ as a function of the Si/Al ratio. As shown in Fig. 5(a)–(c), the rates in hydration of hydrophobic epoxides (1,2-epoxycyclohexane and 1,2-epoxycyclooctane) showed volcano-type dependence on the Si/Al ratio, whereas the rate in hydration of hydrophilic epoxide (propylene oxide) gradually decreased with decreases in the Si/Al ratio. The same trends were observed for the hydration of hydrophobic alkynes (phenylacetylene, diphenylacetylene, and 1-ethynyl-3,5-dimethoxybenzene) and hydrophilic alkyne (3-butyn-2-ol) (Fig. 5(d)–(g)). Taking into account the dependencies of hydrophilicity, hydrophobicity, and acidity of Hβ on the Si/Al ratio, the reaction rate trends can be explained as follows. First, the higher yield of the Si-rich Hβ for hydrophobic substrates was due to the strong interaction of hydrophobic pores with substrates and the moderate number of active acid sites. By contrast, the higher yield of Al-rich Hβ for hydration of hydrophilic substrates was derived from the hydrophilic interaction between zeolite pores and substrates as well as the higher number of acid sites. To support the above consideration, we further carried out the hydration of propylene oxide using Hβ-5, which was expected to show higher activity for hydrophilic substrate. Hβ-5 exhibited a much higher initial reaction rate and TOF compared to the Hβ with higher Si/Al ratio (Eq. (4)). (4) The hydrations of hydrophobic epoxide (1,2-epoxycyclohexane) and alkyne (phenylacetylene) in 1,4-dioxane/water mixture were also examined. The rates in both reactions gradually decreased with increases in the Si/Al ratio (Fig. 6 ). In the presence of 1,4-dioxane, the hydrophobic interaction between Hβ pores and substrates is weakened through the competitive interaction of 1,4-dioxane with the pores and the solvation of substrates in 1,4-dioxane, resulting in the change of the volcano-type dependency of reaction rates on the Si/Al ratio. Furthermore, the TOF values for hydration of hydrophobic substrates in water were calculated from the yield and the amount of acid sites of Hβ. The trends of TOF values as a function of the Si/Al ratio combined with acidity, hydrophilicity, and hydrophobicity are summarized in Fig. 7 . The trend of hydrophilicity is the most similar to those of TOF values, while the trends of acidity and hydrophilicity are completely different. In short, hydrophobicity was found to be a key factor affecting catalytic activity of Hβ zeolites in hydrations, and the highest yield of Hβ-75 among the Hβ tested was attributed to the strong hydrophobic interaction between the pores and substrates. 3.5 Effect of zeolite pore size and substrate size on the catalytic activity The effect of zeolite pore size was also investigated through the hydration of epoxides and alkynes using zeolite Hβ-75 (7.3 Å × 7.6 Å) and HZSM5-75 (5.3 Å × 5.6 Å) with different pore sizes. We summarized the initial reaction rates for two types of zeolites and the estimated minimum cross diameters of substrates (Table 6). For the substrates larger than the pore size of HZSM5-75, such as 1,2-epoxycyclohexane (5.7 Å × 7.6 Å), 1,2-epoxycyclooctane (6.1 Å × 7.8 Å), ethyl 3-phenylglycidate (6.4 Å × 7.4 Å), and diphenylacetylene (5.2 Å × 6.8 Å), Hβ-75 showed higher initial reaction rates compared to HZSM5-75 (entries 2–4 and 7). In particular, the rate by Hβ-75 for 1-ethynyl-3,5-dimethoxybenzene (4.1 Å × 10.1 Å) was much higher than that of HZSM5-75 (entry 8). In the case of propylene oxide (4.4 Å × 4.7 Å), 3-butyn-2-ol (5.8 Å × 6.2 Å), and phenylacetylene (3.6 Å × 6.8 Å), having similar sizes to or smaller sizes than the pore size of HZSM5-75, the reaction rates by HZSM5-75 were higher than those of Hβ-75 (entries 1, 5, and 6). These results indicate that the pore size of zeolite has impact on its activity for hydration. To get insight into the pore size effect, we carried out the adsorption experiment using ethyl 3-phenylglycidate (entry 4) which does not react over the zeolite catalysts at room temperature. The adsorption amounts for Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75 were almost the same (1.1 and 1.35 mmolg−1, respectively). This result suggests that bulky substrates can access into the pore of both zeolites through hydrophobic interaction but the smaller pore of HZSM5-75 would inhibit formation of the corresponding transition state structure or diffusion of the product. As a result, Hβ-75 afforded higher yields than HZSM5-75 for bulky model substrates 1,2-epoxycyclohexane (entry 2) and diphenylacetylene (entry 6). 4 Conclusion Hβ-75 acted as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes in water. This catalyst showed high TON, wide substrate scope, applicability to gram-scale synthesis, and reusability, while maintaining its activity. The effects of hydrophobicity, number of Brønsted acid sites, and pore size of zeolite on its activity were quantitatively studied by the adsorption experiments of H2O and n-dodecane, as well as the kinetic studies of hydration of diverse substrates using two types of zeolites with different Si/Al ratios. The key factor for high yields using Hβ-75 for hydration of hydrophobic substrates was found to be the hydrophobic interaction of the zeolite pore with substrates. The larger pore size of Hβ-75 compared to HZSM5-75 also played an important role in achieving high yields. coredata.dc:description: We investigated the hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes in water using 24 types of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts and found that Hbeta (Hβ) zeolite with a relatively high Si/Al ratio (Si/Al = 75), Hβ-75, is an effective catalyst. Hβ-75 showed wide substrate scope, good reusability, and applicability in gram-scale synthesis for both types of reactions. The effects of hydrophobicity, acidity, and the size of zeolite pores were also comprehensively studied through the hydration of hydrophilic and hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes with different molecular sizes using two types of zeolite (Hβ and HZSM5). The high yields obtained using the Hβ-75 catalyst in the hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes are attributed to the hydrophobic interaction between zeolite pores with the substrates, as well as the relatively large pore size.
coredata.dc:title: High-silica Hβ zeolites for catalytic hydration of hydrophobic epoxides and alkynes in water
